Definitions.Definition_Content: Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A left coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $aH = \{ah; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A right coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $Ha = \{ha; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
A subgroup $H \subset G$ is called a normal subgroup of $G$ if $aH = Ha$ for all $a \in G$, i.e., if for each element $a \in G$ the associated left and right cosets of $H$ in $G$ coincide.

Given a normal subgroup $N \subset G$ of a group $G$, the factor group or the residue class group of $G$ modulo $N$, denoted $G / N$, is the group formed by the set of left cosets of $N$ in $G$ with the group operation defined by $(aN) \cdot (bN) = (ab)N$ for $a, b \in G$.

Theorems.Theorem_Content: Any two left cosets of $H$ in $G$ have the same cardinality and are disjoint if they do not coincide. In particular, $G$ is the disjoint union of all left cosets of $H$ in $G$.
Let $aH$ and $bH$ be left cosets of $H$ in $G$. The following conditions are equivalent: (i) $aH = bH$. (ii) $aH \cap bH \neq \emptyset$. (iii) $a \in bH$. (iv) $b^{-1}a \in H$.
Let $G$ be a finite group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. Then $\operatorname{ord} G = \operatorname{ord} H \cdot (G: H)$.

Let $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\prime}$ be a group homomorphism and $N \subset G$ a normal subgroup such that $N \subset \operatorname{ker} \varphi$. Then there exists a unique group homomorphism $\bar{\varphi}: G / N \longrightarrow G^{\prime}$ satisfying $\varphi = \bar{\varphi} \circ \pi$, where $\pi$ is the projection $G \longrightarrow G / N$.
If $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\prime}$ is a surjective group homomorphism, then $G^{\prime}$ is canonically isomorphic to $G / \operatorname{ker} \varphi$.

Let $G$ be a group, $H \subset G$ a subgroup, and $N \subset G$ a normal subgroup of $G$. Then $HN$ is a subgroup of $G$ admitting $N$ as a normal subgroup, and $H \cap N$ is a normal subgroup of $H$. The canonical homomorphism $H / H \cap N \longrightarrow HN / N$ is an isomorphism.

Let $G$ be a group and let $N, H$ be normal subgroups of $G$ satisfying $N \subset H \subset G$. Then $N$ is normal in $H$ as well, and one can view $H / N$ as a normal subgroup of $G / N$. Furthermore, the canonical group homomorphism $(G / N) /(H / N) \longrightarrow G / H$ is an isomorphism.
